example[0]: Don’t stand so near the edge! You’re frightening me.
example[1]: She was frightened by the anger in his eyes.
example[2]: Computers used to frighten me, but not now.
example[3]: He drove at a speed which frightened Lara to death.
note[0]: frighten somebody to death/frighten the life out of somebody
example[4]: The thought of being in court frightened him.
definition[1]: to frighten someone. Scare is less formal than frighten, and is the usual word to use in everyday English
example[5]: He was driving fast just to scare us.
example[6]: It scared him to think that his mother might never recover.
definition[2]: to make someone feel extremely frightened
example[7]: The idea of going down into the caves terrified her.
example[8]: Robbers terrified bank staff by threatening them at gunpoint.
definition[3]: to make someone suddenly feel frightened in a way that makes their heart beat more quickly
example[9]: It gave me a terrible fright when I found him unconscious on the floor.
definition[4]: if a person or place gives you the creeps, they make you feel slightly frightened because they are strange
example[10]: This house gives me the creeps.
definition[5]: to frighten someone. Used when you suddenly see someone and did not know they were there, or when you suddenly hear something
example[11]: I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to startle you.
example[12]: The noise startled him, and he dropped his glass on the floor.
definition[6]: to make someone feel frightened and worried that something bad might happen
example[13]: I didn’t want to alarm her by calling in the middle of the night.
definition[7]: to deliberately frighten someone, especially so that they will do what you want
example[14]: Many of the gangs were using dogs to intimidate people.
